story.iWant: a toolkit of interactive activities I can deploy during or between sessions
story.soThat: learning is varied, engaging, and uses evidence-based techniques beyond pure conversation

context.applies: Any tutoring session where the agent has an identity spec and curriculum
assumptions: Voice-native activities require no infrastructure — the AI executes them conversationally
Text activities require a send_text_to_caller VAPI tool
Activity selection is context-aware based on personality, mastery, session phase, and time gaps
The AI has autonomy to choose WHEN to deploy activities — the spec provides the WHAT and HOW

parameters.name: Activity Catalog
parameters.description: All available interaction activities with formats and triggers

activities.name: Pop Quiz
activities.description: A quick, unexpected question to check retention or understanding of recently taught material

steps: Announce casually: 'Quick one for you...' or 'Let me test something...'
Ask ONE clear, specific question about a concept you've covered
Wait for their full answer — do NOT interrupt or hint
Give specific feedback: what was right, what to refine
If wrong, briefly re-teach then move on — don't dwell

when: After teaching a new concept (comprehension check)
At session start for returning callers (spaced retrieval)
When caller claims understanding but you haven't verified
When energy seems to be dropping (pattern break)
avoid_when: Caller is frustrated or anxious
First 2 minutes of a first-ever call
Immediately after they got something wrong

personality_adaptations.high_neuroticism: Preface with reassurance: 'This isn't a test, just want to see where we are'
personality_adaptations.high_openness: Make questions more creative or unexpected

activities.name: Multiple Choice (Voice)
activities.description: Present 3-4 options verbally and ask the caller to choose

steps: State the question clearly
Present 3-4 options with labels: 'A, B, C, or D'
Keep options short enough to remember verbally (max 10 words each)
Wait for their choice
If correct: affirm and explain WHY it's right
If wrong: explain why their choice seemed reasonable, then clarify the correct answer
format.difficulty_range: slightly below to at mastery level

when: Reviewing material from previous sessions
Checking understanding of distinctions between similar concepts
Building exam readiness (if curriculum has exam component)
Caller seems to prefer structured questions over open ones
avoid_when: Topic is too complex for discrete options
Caller prefers open-ended exploration
First call with no taught material yet

personality_adaptations.low_openness: Stick to clearly defined, concrete options
personality_adaptations.high_conscientiousness: Caller will appreciate the structured format — lean into it
personality_adaptations.low_extraversion: Give extra thinking time: 'Take a moment to consider...'

activities.name: Multiple Choice (Text/SMS)
activities.description: Send a formatted MCQ via text so the caller can read options at their own pace

steps: Tell the caller: 'I'm sending you a question by text — have a look and tell me what you think'
Use send_text_to_caller tool with formatted question
Wait for their verbal or text response
Discuss their answer, whether right or wrong
format.difficulty_range: at or slightly above mastery level

when: Options are too long or complex for voice-only
Caller is a visual/read-write learner (high VARK-R)
Exam preparation with real exam-style questions
Mid-session as a change of pace
avoid_when: Caller is driving or can't look at phone
No phone number available for SMS

personality_adaptations.high_conscientiousness: Great fit — they'll engage carefully with written options
personality_adaptations.low_extraversion: Preferred over verbal MCQ — less pressure to respond quickly

activities.name: Rapid Fire True/False
activities.description: 3-5 quick true/false statements to test factual recall in rapid succession

steps: Set up: 'Let's do a quick rapid fire — I'll say a statement, you tell me true or false. Ready?'
State 3-5 short, clear factual statements
Accept brief answers (true/false/yes/no)
Keep pace brisk but not stressful
After the round: review any they got wrong, celebrate what they nailed
format.difficulty_range: recall level — facts they should know

when: Spaced retrieval phase of returning caller session
End of session as a fun recap
Caller has high energy and seems ready for a challenge
Multiple simple facts need verification
avoid_when: Caller is tentative or low confidence
Concepts are nuanced (not suited to true/false)
First session — no established knowledge base yet

personality_adaptations.high_extraversion: Increase pace, make it competitive: 'Let's see how many you can nail'
personality_adaptations.low_extraversion: Slower pace, fewer items (3 max), no time pressure
personality_adaptations.high_neuroticism: Frame as 'just a quick check' not a 'test', offer encouragement between

activities.name: Scenario / What-If
activities.description: Present a realistic scenario and ask the caller how they'd handle it, applying what they've learned

steps: Paint a brief, vivid scenario relevant to the curriculum
Ask: 'What would you do?' or 'How would you handle this?'
Let them think and respond fully
Discuss their reasoning — what's strong, what to consider
If relevant, connect to the formal concept or rule
format.difficulty_range: application level — requires understanding, not just recall

when: After a concept has been taught and basic recall confirmed
Building toward exam scenarios
Caller learns best through practical application
Bridging theory to practice
avoid_when: Basic recall hasn't been established yet
Caller is struggling with fundamentals
Time is running short in session

personality_adaptations.high_openness: Make scenarios more creative, unusual, or thought-provoking
personality_adaptations.low_openness: Keep scenarios concrete, realistic, and clearly connected to what was taught
personality_adaptations.high_conscientiousness: Include specific details and constraints in the scenario
personality_adaptations.high_extraversion: Encourage them to think out loud as they work through it

activities.name: Teach It Back
activities.description: Ask the caller to explain a concept as if teaching someone else — the ultimate comprehension check

steps: Frame it: 'Imagine you had to explain [concept] to a friend who knows nothing about it. How would you put it?'
Listen to their full explanation without interrupting
Note what they included, missed, or got wrong
Affirm what they got right, gently fill gaps: 'Great — you'd also want to mention...'
Use log_activity_result to record comprehension level
format.difficulty_range: deep understanding — they must synthesize, not just recall

when: Caller has been studying a concept across multiple sessions
Before moving to the next major topic (mastery gate)
Caller says they 'get it' — verify with teach-back
Preparing for an exam
avoid_when: Concept was just introduced this session
Caller is not confident yet — could feel like being put on the spot
Very early in the learning journey

personality_adaptations.low_extraversion: Make it less performative: 'In your own words, what would you say the key idea is?'
personality_adaptations.high_neuroticism: Reassure: 'There's no perfect answer — just tell me how you think about it'
personality_adaptations.high_extraversion: They'll enjoy this — let them run with it

activities.name: Reflection Prompt (Text)
activities.description: Send a reflective question via text for the caller to think about between sessions

steps: Near end of session: 'I'll send you something to think about before next time'
Use send_text_to_caller with a thought-provoking question
Question should connect what they learned to their life or goals
In next session, reference the prompt: 'Did you think about that question I sent?'
format.duration: 30 sec (to send), follows up next session

when: End of a productive session
Caller has shown interest in deeper understanding
Bridging material across sessions
Building metacognitive habits
avoid_when: First session — too early for homework
Caller seems overwhelmed
Session ended on a frustrating note

personality_adaptations.high_openness: Ask more abstract, philosophical reflection questions
personality_adaptations.high_conscientiousness: They'll actually do it — make it meaningful

activities.name: Spaced Retrieval (Text)
activities.description: Timed text message between sessions to trigger retrieval practice at optimal intervals

steps: System sends text at scheduled interval (1/3/7/14 days after learning)
Question focuses on key concept from a past session
Caller can reply by text or discuss in next call
Track whether they responded and incorporate into next session
format.difficulty_range: recall level — match to spaced repetition interval

when: Automatically based on spaced repetition schedule
High-stakes concepts that need reinforcement
Caller has opted into between-session practice
avoid_when: Caller hasn't opted in to text messages
Too many texts already sent (max 2 per week)
Caller explicitly asked not to be texted

personality_adaptations.low_conscientiousness: Keep messages shorter, less frequent, more casual
personality_adaptations.high_neuroticism: Frame as casual check-in, not a test

parameters.name: Activity Selection Strategy
parameters.description: How the AI should choose which activities to use

principles: Activities serve learning — never use one just for novelty
Match activity to session phase: retrieval activities early, application activities later
Adapt frequency to personality: high conscientiousness can handle more structure, high openness prefers variety
One structured activity per session is usually enough — don't overdo it
Voice-native activities are the default; use text only when it genuinely helps
Always gauge the moment — if the caller is in flow, don't break it with a forced activity

constraints.description: Activities must serve learning objectives — never use as filler or to show off
Never send text messages without caller consent or if no phone number available
Activity difficulty must match current mastery level — never humiliate with too-hard questions
Maximum 2 structured activities per session, minimum 5 minutes apart
